Federated Learning of a Mixture of Global and Local Models

Filip Hanzely King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
Thuwal, Saudi Arabia Peter Richtárik King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
Thuwal, Saudi Arabia
(February 14, 2020)
Abstract

We propose a new optimization formulation for training federated learning models. The standard formulation has the form of an empirical risk minimization problem constructed to find a single global model trained from the private data stored across all participating devices. In contrast, our formulation seeks an explicit trade-off between this traditional global model and the local models, which can be learned by each device from its own private data without any communication. Further, we develop several efficient variants of SGD (with and without partial participation and with and without variance reduction) for solving the new formulation and prove communication complexity guarantees. Notably, our methods are similar but not identical to federated averaging / local SGD, thus shedding some light on the role of local steps in federated learning. In particular, we are the first to i) show that local steps can improve communication for problems with heterogeneous data, and ii) point out that personalization yields reduced communication complexity.

1 Introduction

With the proliferation of mobile phones, wearable devices, tablets, and smart home devices comes an increase in the volume of data captured and stored on them. This data contains a wealth of potentially useful information to the owners of these devices, and more so if appropriate machine learning models could be trained on the heterogeneous data stored across the network of such devices. The traditional approach involves moving the relevant data to a data center where centralized machine learning techniques can be efficiently applied (Dean et al., 2012; Reddi et al., 2016). However, this approach is not without issues. First, many device users are increasingly sensitive to privacy concerns and prefer their data to never leave their devices. Second, moving data from their place of origin to a centralized location is very inefficient in terms of energy and time.

1.1 Federated learning

Federated learning (FL) (McMahan et al., 2016; Konečný et al., 2016b, a; McMahan et al., 2017) has emerged as an interdisciplinary field focused on addressing these issues by training machine learning models directly on edge devices. The currently prevalent paradigm (Li et al., 2019; Kairouz et al., 2019) casts supervised FL as an empirical risk minimization problem of the form

minx∈ℝd⁡1n​∑i=1nfi​(x),subscript𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\min\limits_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x), (1)

where n𝑛n is the number of devices participating in training, x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} encodes the d𝑑d parameters of a global model (e.g., weights of a neural network) and

fi​(x)≔𝔼ξ∼𝒟i​[f​(x,ξ)]≔subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉subscript𝒟𝑖delimited-[]𝑓𝑥𝜉f_{i}(x)\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim{\cal D}_{i}}\left[f(x,\xi)\right]

represents the aggregate loss of model x𝑥x on the local data represented by distribution 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\cal D}_{i} stored on device i𝑖i. One of the defining characteristics of FL is that the data distributions 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\cal D}_{i} may possess very different properties across the devices. Hence, any potential FL method is explicitly required to be able to work under the heterogeneous data setting.

The most popular method for solving (1) in the context of FL is the FedAvg algorithm (McMahan et al., 2016). In its most simple form, when one does not employ partial participation, model compression, or stochastic approximation, FedAvg reduces to Local Gradient Descent (LGD) (Khaled et al., 2019, 2020), which is an extension of GD performing more than a single gradient step on each device before aggregation. FedAvg has been shown to work well empirically, particularly for non-convex problems, but comes with poor convergence guarantees compared to the non-local counterparts when data are heterogeneous.

1.2 Some issues with current approaches to FL

The first motivation for our research comes from the appreciation that data heterogeneity does not merely present challenges to the design of new provably efficient training methods for solving (1), but also inevitably raises questions about the utility of such a global solution to individual users. Indeed, a global model trained across all the data from all devices might be so removed from the typical data and usage patterns experienced by an individual user as to render it virtually useless. This issue has been observed before, and various approaches have been proposed to address it. For instance, the MOCHA (Smith et al., 2017) framework uses a multi-task learning approach to allow for personalization. Next, (Khodak et al., 2019) propose a generic online algorithm for gradient-based parameter-transfer meta-learning and demonstrate improved practical performance over FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017). Approaches based on variational inference (Corinzia & Buhmann, 2019), cyclic patterns in practical FL data sampling (Eichner et al., 2019) transfer learning (Zhao et al., 2018) and explicit model mixing (Peterson et al., 2019) have been proposed.

The second motivation for our work is the realization that even very simple variants of FedAvg, such as LGD, which should be easier to analyze, fail to provide theoretical improvements in communication complexity over their non-local cousins, in this case, GD (Khaled et al., 2019, 2020).111After our paper was completed, a lower bound on the performance of local SGD was presented that is worse than the known minibatch SGD guarantee (Woodworth et al., 2020a), confirming that the local methods do not outperform their non-local counterparts in the heterogeneous setup. Similarly, the benefit of local methods in the non-heterogeneous scenario was questioned in (Woodworth et al., 2020b).

This observation is at odds with the practical success of local methods in FL. This leads us to ask the question:

If LGD does not theoretically improve upon GD as a solver for the traditional global problem (1), perhaps LGD should not be seen as a method for solving (1) at all. In such a case, what problem does LGD solve?

A good answer to this question would shed light on the workings of LGD, and by analogy, on the role local steps play in more elaborate FL methods such as local SGD (Stich, 2020; Khaled et al., 2020) and FedAvg.

2 Contributions

In our work we argue that the two motivations mentioned in the introduction point in the same direction, i.e., we show that a single solution can be devised addressing both problems at the same time. Our main contributions are:

⋄⋄\diamond New formulation of FL which seeks an implicit mixture of global and local models. We propose a new optimization formulation of FL. Instead of learning a single global model by solving (1), we propose to learn a mixture of the global model and the purely local models which can be trained by each device i𝑖i using its data 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\cal D}_{i} only. Our formulation (see Sec. 3) lifts the problem from ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} to ℝn​dsuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑑\mathbb{R}^{nd}, allowing each device i𝑖i to learn a personalized model xi∈ℝdsubscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. These personalized models are encouraged to not depart too much from their mean by the inclusion of a quadratic penalty ψ𝜓\psi multiplied by a parameter λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0. Admittedly, the idea of softly-enforced similarity of the local models was already introduced in the domain of the multi-task relationship learning (Zhang & Yeung, 2010; Liu et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2018) and distributed optimization (Lan et al., 2018; Gorbunov et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2015). The mixture objective we propose (see (2)) is a special case of their setup, which justifies our approach from the modeling perspective. Note that Zhang et al. (2015); Liu et al. (2017); Wang et al. (2018) provide efficient algorithms to solve the mixture objective already. However, none of the mentioned papers consider the FL application, nor they shed a light on the communication complexity of LGD algorithms, which we do in our work.

⋄⋄\diamond Theoretical properties of the new formulation. We study the properties of the optimal solution of our formulation, thus developing an algorithmic-free theory. When the penalty parameter is set to zero, then obviously, each device is allowed to train their own model without any dependence on the data stored on other devices. Such purely local models are rarely useful. We prove that the optimal local models converge to the traditional global model characterized by (1) at the rate 𝒪​(1/λ)𝒪1𝜆{\cal O}(1/\lambda). We also show that the total loss evaluated at the local models is never higher than the total loss evaluated at the global model (see Thm. 3.1). Moreover, we prove an insightful structural result for the optimal local models: the optimal model learned by device i𝑖i arises by subtracting the gradient of the loss function stored on that device evaluated at the same point (i.e., a local model) from the average of the optimal local models (see Thm. 3.2). As a byproduct, this theoretical result sheds new light on the key update step in the model agnostic meta-learning (MAML) method (Finn et al., 2017), which has a similar but subtly different structure.222The connection of FL and multi-task meta learning is discussed in (Kairouz et al., 2019), for example. The subtle difference is that the MAML update obtains the local model by subtracting the gradient evaluated at the global model. While MAML was originally proposed as a heuristic, we provide rigorous theoretical guarantees.

⋄⋄\diamond Loopless LGD: non-uniform SGD applied to our formulation. We then propose a randomized gradient-based method—Loopless Local Gradient Descent (L2GD)—for solving our new formulation (Algorithm 1). This method is, in fact, a non-standard application of SGD to our problem, and can be seen as an instance of SGD with non-uniform sampling applied to the problem of minimizing the sum of two convex functions (Zhao & Zhang, 2015; Gower et al., 2019): the average loss, and the penalty. When the loss function is selected by the randomness in our SGD method, the stochastic gradient step can be interpreted as the execution of a single local GD step on each device. Since we set the probability of the loss being sampled to be high, this step is typically repeated multiple times, resulting in multiple local GD steps. In contrast to standard LGD, the number of local steps is not fixed, but random, and follows a geometric distribution. This mechanism is similar in spirit to how the recently proposed loopless variants of SVRG (Hofmann et al., 2015; Kovalev et al., 2020) work in comparison with the original SVRG (Johnson & Zhang, 2013; Xiao & Zhang, 2014). Once the penalty is sampled by our method, the resultant SGD step can be interpreted as the execution of an aggregation step. In contrast with standard aggregation, which performs full averaging of the local models, our method merely takes a step towards averaging. However, the step is relatively large. We stress that the difference in terms of the algorithm statement between L2GD and LGD is rather minor as the main essence of these methods is identical. The key difference lies in the problem that the algorithms are employed to solve, and the resulting communication complexity.

⋄⋄\diamond Convergence theory. By adapting the general theory from (Gower et al., 2019) to our setting, we obtain theoretical convergence guarantees assuming that each fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is L𝐿L-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex (see Thm. 4.5). Interestingly, by optimizing the probability of sampling the penalty (we get p⋆=λλ+Lsuperscript𝑝⋆𝜆𝜆𝐿p^{\star}=\tfrac{\lambda}{\lambda+L}), which is an indirect way of fixing the expected number of local steps to 1+Lλ1𝐿𝜆1+\tfrac{L}{\lambda}, we prove an

2​λλ+L​Lμ​log⁡1ε2𝜆𝜆𝐿𝐿𝜇1𝜀\tfrac{2\lambda}{\lambda+L}\tfrac{L}{\mu}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}

bound on the expected number of communication rounds (see Cor. 4.6). We believe that this is remarkable in several ways. By choosing λ𝜆\lambda small, we tilt our goal towards pure local models: the number of communication rounds is tending to 0 as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0. If λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, the solution our formulation converges to is the optimal global model, and L2GD obtains the communication bound 𝒪​(Lμ​log⁡1ε)𝒪𝐿𝜇1𝜀{\cal O}\left(\tfrac{L}{\mu}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\right), which matches the efficiency of GD.

⋄⋄\diamond Personalization, local steps and communication complexity. Indeed, to the best of our knowledge, there is no result in the literature showing that local SGD communicates less than SGD on the classical FL (1) with heterogeneous data. We are the first to show that (variants of) local SGD can outperform (synchronous) minibatch SGD in communication complexity if no data similarity is assumed.333Admittedly, local steps can reduce the communication complexity when some measure of data dissimilarity is bounded. However, data homogeneity assumptions are highly contentious in FL applications. However, as we argue in the next point, this happens with a twist: local methods need to be seen as algorithms for solving our personalized FL objective instead. Consequently, we are also the first to show that personalized FL444While we show it only for a particular personalized FL objective, we suspect that such a phenomenon applies to other personalized FL objectives too. can be easier to solve, in terms of communication complexity, compared to the traditional FL objective (1).

⋄⋄\diamond What problem do local methods solve? Noting that L2GD is a (mildly nonstandard) version of LGD,555To be specific, L2GD is equivalent to Overlap LGD (Wang et al., 2020) with random local loop size. which is a key method most local methods for FL are based on, and noting that, as we show, L2GD solves our new formulation of FL, we offer a new and surprising interpretation of the role of local steps in FL. As mentioned, the role of local steps in the classical FL formulation (1) with heterogeneous data is not to reduce the communication complexity. Instead, their role is to steer the method towards finding a mixture of the traditional global and the purely local models. Given that the stepsize is fixed, the more local steps are taken, the more we bias the method towards the purely local models. Our new optimization formulation of FL formalizes this as it defines the problem that local methods, in this case L2GD, solve. There is an added benefit here: the more we want our formulation to be biased towards purely local models (i.e., the smaller the penalty parameter λ𝜆\lambda is), the more local steps does L2GD take, and the better the total communication complexity of L2GD becomes. Hence, despite a lot of research on this topic, our paper provides the first proof that a local method (e.g., L2GD) can be better than its non-local counterpart (e.g., GD) in terms of total communication complexity in the heterogeneous data setting. We are able to do this by noting that local methods should better be seen as methods for solving the new FL formulation proposed here.

⋄⋄\diamond Generalizations: partial participation, local SGD and variance reduction. We further generalize and improve our method by allowing for (i) stochastic partial participation of devices in each communication round,(ii) subsampling on each device which means we can perform local SGD steps instead of local GD steps, and (iii) total variance reduction mechanism to tackle the variance coming from three sources: locality of the updates induced by non-uniform sampling (already present in L2GD), partial participation and local subsampling. Due to its level of generality, this method, which we call L2SGD++, is presented in the Appendix only, alongside the associated complexity results. In the main body of this paper, we instead present a simplified version thereof, which we call L2SGD+ (Algorithm 2). The convergence theory for it is presented in Thm. 5.1 and Cor. 5.2.

⋄⋄\diamond Heterogeneous data. All our methods and convergence results allow for fully heterogeneous data and do not depend on any assumptions on data similarity across the devices.

⋄⋄\diamond Superior empirical performance. We show through ample numerical experiments that our theoretical predictions can be observed in practice.

3 New Formulation of FL

We now introduce our new formulation for training supervised FL models:

minx1,…,xn∈ℝdsubscriptsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑\displaystyle\min\limits_{x_{1},\dots,x_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}} {F​(x)≔f​(x)+λ​ψ​(x)}≔𝐹𝑥𝑓𝑥𝜆𝜓𝑥\displaystyle\left\{F(x)\coloneqq f(x)+\lambda\psi(x)\right\} (2)
f(x)≔1n∑i=1nfi(\displaystyle f(x)\coloneqq\tfrac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}( xi),ψ(x)≔12​n∑i=1n∥xi−x¯∥2,\displaystyle x_{i}),\quad\psi(x)\coloneqq\tfrac{1}{2n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left\|x_{i}-\bar{x}\right\|^{2},

where λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0 is a penalty parameter, x1,…,xn∈ℝdsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑x_{1},\dots,x_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} are local models, x≔(x1,x2,…,xn)∈ℝn​d≔𝑥subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑x\coloneqq(x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n})\in\mathbb{R}^{nd} and x¯≔1n​∑i=1nxi≔¯𝑥1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖\bar{x}\coloneqq\tfrac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i} is the average of the local models.

Due to the assumptions on fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} we will make in Sec. 3.1, F𝐹F is strongly convex and hence (2) has a unique solution, which we denote

x​(λ)≔(x1​(λ),…,xn​(λ))∈ℝn​d.≔𝑥𝜆subscript𝑥1𝜆…subscript𝑥𝑛𝜆superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑x(\lambda)\coloneqq(x_{1}(\lambda),\dots,x_{n}(\lambda))\in\mathbb{R}^{nd}.

We further let x¯​(λ)≔1n​∑i=1nxi​(λ)≔¯𝑥𝜆1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆\bar{x}(\lambda)\coloneqq\tfrac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}(\lambda). We now comment on the rationale behind the new formulation.

Local models (λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0). Note that for each i𝑖i, xi​(0)subscript𝑥𝑖0x_{i}(0) solves the local problem

minxi∈ℝd⁡fi​(xi).subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖\min\limits_{x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f_{i}(x_{i}).

That is, xi​(0)subscript𝑥𝑖0x_{i}(0) is the local model based on data 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\cal D}_{i} stored on device i𝑖i only. This model can be computed by device i𝑖i without any communication whatsoever. Typically, 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\cal D}_{i} is not rich enough for this local model to be useful. In order to learn a better model, one has to take into account the date from other clients as well. This, however, requires communication.

Mixed models (λ∈(0,∞)𝜆0\lambda\in(0,\infty)). As λ𝜆\lambda increases, the penalty λ​ψ​(x)𝜆𝜓𝑥\lambda\psi(x) has an increasingly more substantial effect, and communication is needed to ensure that the models are not too dissimilar, as otherwise the penalty λ​ψ​(x)𝜆𝜓𝑥\lambda\psi(x) would be too large.

Global model (λ=∞𝜆\lambda=\infty). Let us now look at the limit case λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty. Intuitively, this limit case should force the optimal local models to be mutually identical, while minimizing the loss f𝑓f. In particular, this limit case will solve666If λ=∞𝜆\lambda=\infty and x1=x2=⋯=xnsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2⋯subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1}=x_{2}=\dots=x_{n} does not hold, we have F​(x)=∞𝐹𝑥F(x)=\infty. Therefore, we can restrict ourselves on set x1=x2=⋯=xnsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2⋯subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1}=x_{2}=\dots=x_{n} without loss of generality.

min⁡{f​(x):x1,…,xn∈ℝd,x1=x2=⋯=xn},:𝑓𝑥subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2⋯subscript𝑥𝑛\min\left\{f(x)\;:\;x_{1},\dots,x_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\;x_{1}=x_{2}=\dots=x_{n}\right\},

which is equivalent to the global formulation (2). Because of this, let us define xi​(∞)subscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}(\infty) for each i𝑖i to be the optimal global solution of (1), and let x​(∞)≔(x1​(∞),…,xn​(∞))≔𝑥subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x(\infty)\coloneqq(x_{1}(\infty),\dots,x_{n}(\infty)).

3.1 Technical preliminaries

We make the following assumption on the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}:

Assumption 3.1

For each i𝑖i, the function fi:ℝd→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝑖→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} is L𝐿L-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex.

3.2 Characterization of optimal solutions

Our first result describes the behavior of f​(x​(λ))𝑓𝑥𝜆f(x(\lambda)) and ψ​(x​(λ))𝜓𝑥𝜆\psi(x(\lambda)) as a function of λ𝜆\lambda.

Theorem 3.1

The function λ→ψ​(x​(λ))→𝜆𝜓𝑥𝜆\lambda\to\psi(x(\lambda)) is non-increasing, and for all λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 we have

ψ​(x​(λ))≤f​(x​(∞))−f​(x​(0))λ.𝜓𝑥𝜆𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑥0𝜆\psi(x(\lambda))\leq\tfrac{f(x(\infty))-f(x(0))}{\lambda}. (3)

Moreover, the function λ→f​(x​(λ))→𝜆𝑓𝑥𝜆\lambda\to f(x(\lambda)) is non-decreasing, and for all λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0 we have

f​(x​(λ))≤f​(x​(∞)).𝑓𝑥𝜆𝑓𝑥f(x(\lambda))\leq f(x(\infty)). (4)

Ineq. (3) says that the penalty decreases to zero as λ𝜆\lambda grows, and hence the optimal local models xi​(λ)subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆x_{i}(\lambda) are increasingly similar as λ𝜆\lambda grows. The second statement suggest that the loss f​(x​(λ))𝑓𝑥𝜆f(x(\lambda)) increases with λ𝜆\lambda, but never exceeds the optimal global loss f​(x​(∞))𝑓𝑥f(x(\infty)) of the standard FL formulation (1).

We now characterize the optimal local models which connect our model to the MAML framework (Finn et al., 2017), as mentioned in the introduction.

Theorem 3.2

For each λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 and 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n we have

xi​(λ)=x¯​(λ)−1λ​∇fi​(xi​(λ)).subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆¯𝑥𝜆1𝜆∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆x_{i}(\lambda)=\overline{x}(\lambda)-\tfrac{1}{\lambda}\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda)). (5)

Further, we have ∑i=1n∇fi​(xi​(λ))=0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆0\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda))=0 and

ψ​(x​(λ))=12​λ2​‖∇f​(x​(λ))‖2.𝜓𝑥𝜆12superscript𝜆2superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝑥𝜆2\psi(x(\lambda))=\tfrac{1}{2\lambda^{2}}\left\|\nabla f(x(\lambda))\right\|^{2}.

The optimal local models (​5​)italic-(5italic-)\eqref{eq:step_from_mean} are obtained from the average model by subtracting a multiple of the local gradient. Observe that the local gradients always sum up to zero at optimality. This is obviously true for λ=∞𝜆\lambda=\infty, but it is a bit less obvious that this holds for any λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0.

Next, we argue the optimal local models converge to the traditional FL solution at the rate 𝒪​(1/λ)𝒪1𝜆{\cal O}(1/\lambda).

Theorem 3.3

Let P​(z)≔1n​∑i=1nfi​(z)≔𝑃𝑧1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑧P(z)\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(z). Then, x​(∞)𝑥x(\infty) is the unique minimizer of P𝑃P and we have

‖∇P​(x¯​(λ))‖2≤2​L2λ​(f​(x​(∞))−f​(x​(0))).superscriptnorm∇𝑃¯𝑥𝜆22superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑥0\|\nabla P(\bar{x}(\lambda))\|^{2}\leq\frac{2L^{2}}{\lambda}(f(x(\infty))-f(x(0))). (6)

4 L2GD: Loopless Local GD

In this section we describe a new randomized method for solving the formulation (2). Our method is a non-uniform SGD for (2) seen as a 2-sum problem, sampling either ∇f∇𝑓\nabla f or ∇ψ∇𝜓\nabla\psi to estimate ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F. Letting 0<p<10𝑝10<p<1, we define a stochastic gradient of F𝐹F at x∈ℝn​d𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{nd} as follows

G​(x)≔{∇f​(x)1−pwith probability1−pλ​∇ψ​(x)pwith probabilityp.≔𝐺𝑥cases∇𝑓𝑥1𝑝with probability1𝑝𝜆∇𝜓𝑥𝑝with probability𝑝G(x)\coloneqq\begin{cases}\tfrac{\nabla f(x)}{1-p}&\text{with probability}\quad 1-p\\ \tfrac{\lambda\nabla\psi(x)}{p}&\text{with probability}\quad p\end{cases}. (7)

Clearly, G​(x)𝐺𝑥G(x) is an unbiased estimator of ∇F​(x)∇𝐹𝑥\nabla F(x). This leads to the following method for minimizing F𝐹F, which we call L2GD: xk+1=xk−α​G​(xk).superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘𝛼𝐺superscript𝑥𝑘x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\alpha G(x^{k}). Plugging the formulas for ∇f​(x)∇𝑓𝑥\nabla f(x) and ∇ψ​(x)∇𝜓𝑥\nabla\psi(x) into (7), and writing the resulting method in a distributed manner, we arrive at Algorithm 1. In each iteration, a coin ξ𝜉\xi is tossed and lands 111 with probability p𝑝p and 00 with probability 1−p1𝑝1-p. If ξ=0𝜉0\xi=0, all Devices perform one local GD step (8), and if ξ=1𝜉1\xi=1, Master shifts each local model towards the average via (9). As we shall see in Sec. 4.3, our theory limits the value of the stepsize α𝛼\alpha, which has the effect that the ratio α​λn​p𝛼𝜆𝑛𝑝\tfrac{\alpha\lambda}{np} cannot exceed 1212\tfrac{1}{2}. Hence, (9) is a convex combination of xiksuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘x_{i}^{k} and x¯ksuperscript¯𝑥𝑘\bar{x}^{k}.

Note that Algorithm 1 is only required to communicate when a two consecutive coin tosses land a different value (see the detailed explanation in Sec. 4.2 of the appendix). Consequently, the expected number of communication rounds in k𝑘k iterations of L2GD is p​(1−p)​k𝑝1𝑝𝑘p(1-p)k.

Remark 4.1

Our algorithm statements do not take the data privacy into the consideration. While privacy is a very important aspect of FL; in this paper, we tackle different FL challenges and thus we ignore privacy issues. However, the proposed algorithms can be implemented in a private fashion as well using tricks that are used in the classical FL scenario (Bonawitz et al., 2017).

4.1 The dynamics of local GD and averaging steps

Notice that the average of the local models does not change during an aggregation step. Indeed, x¯k+1superscript¯𝑥𝑘1\bar{x}^{k+1} is equal to

1n​∑i=1nxik+1​=(​9​)​1n​∑i=1n[(1−α​λn​p)​xik+α​λn​p​x¯k]=x¯k.1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘1italic-(9italic-)1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛delimited-[]1𝛼𝜆𝑛𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘𝑖𝛼𝜆𝑛𝑝superscript¯𝑥𝑘superscript¯𝑥𝑘\tfrac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}^{k+1}\overset{\eqref{eq:buiufg98fb}}{=}\tfrac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left[\left(1-\tfrac{\alpha\lambda}{np}\right)x^{k}_{i}+\tfrac{\alpha\lambda}{np}\bar{x}^{k}\right]=\bar{x}^{k}.

If several averaging steps take place in a sequence, the point a=x¯k𝑎superscript¯𝑥𝑘a=\bar{x}^{k} in (9) remains unchanged, and each local model xiksuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘x_{i}^{k} merely moves along the line joining the initial value of the local model at the start of the sequence and a𝑎a, with each step pushing xiksuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘x_{i}^{k} closer to the average a𝑎a.

In summary, the more local GD steps are taken, the closer the local models get to the pure local models; and the more averaging steps are taken, the closer the local models get to their average value. The relative number of local GD vs. averaging steps is controlled by the parameter p𝑝p: the expected # of local GD steps is 1p1𝑝\tfrac{1}{p}, and the expected number of consecutive aggregation steps is 11−p11𝑝\tfrac{1}{1-p}.

4.2 Understanding communication of L2GD

Example 4.2

In order to better understand when communication takes place in Algorithm 1, consider the following possible sequence of coin tosses: 0,0,1,0,1,1,1,0.001011100,0,1,0,1,1,1,0. The first two coin tosses lead to two local GD steps (8) on all devices. The third coin toss lands 111, at which point all local models xiksuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘x_{i}^{k} are communicated to the master, averaged to form x¯ksuperscript¯𝑥𝑘\bar{x}^{k}, and the step (9) towards averaging is taken. The fourth coin toss is 00, and at this point, the master communicates the updated local models back to the devices, which subsequently perform a single local GD step (8). Then come three consecutive coin tosses landing 111, which means that the local models are again communicated to the master, which performs three averaging steps (9). Finally, the eighth coin toss lands 00, which makes the master send the updated local models back to the devices, which subsequently perform a single local GD step.

This example illustrates that communication needs to take place whenever two consecutive coin tosses land a different value. If 00 is followed by a 111, all devices communicate to the master, and if 111 is followed by a 00, the master communicates back to the devices. It is standard to count each pair of communications, Device→→\toMaster and the subsequent Master→→\toDevice, as a single communication round.

Lemma 4.3

The expected number of communication rounds in k𝑘k iterations of L2GD is p​(1−p)​k𝑝1𝑝𝑘p(1-p)k.

Remark 4.4

As stressed in Section 2, L2GD differs from LGD only in terms of the random local loop length and partial averaging. These two differences are minor and keep the essence of the method intact. We only decided to consider L2GD over LGD for the sake of convenience: it allows us to generate local methods as special cases of (existing and novel variants of) SGD. The major novelty of our approach is applying local methods to solve the personalized FL objective (1), which allows us to obtain better communication guarantees and justifies the role of local steps in the heterogeneous data regime.

4.3 Convergence theory

We now present our convergence result for L2GD.

Theorem 4.5

Let Assumption 3.1 hold. If α≤12​ℒ𝛼12ℒ\alpha\leq\tfrac{1}{2{\cal L}}, then

𝔼​[‖xk−x​(λ)‖2]≤(1−α​μn)k​‖x0−x​(λ)‖2+2​n​α​σ2μ,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑘𝑥𝜆2superscript1𝛼𝜇𝑛𝑘superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥0𝑥𝜆22𝑛𝛼superscript𝜎2𝜇\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|x^{k}-x(\lambda)\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\left(1-\tfrac{\alpha\mu}{n}\right)^{k}\left\|x^{0}-x(\lambda)\right\|^{2}+\tfrac{2n\alpha\sigma^{2}}{\mu},

where ℒ≔1n​max⁡{L1−p,λp}≔ℒ1𝑛𝐿1𝑝𝜆𝑝{\cal L}\coloneqq\tfrac{1}{n}\max\left\{\tfrac{L}{1-p},\tfrac{\lambda}{p}\right\} and

σ2≔1n2​∑i=1n(11−p​‖∇fi​(xi​(λ))‖2+λ2p​‖xi​(λ)−x¯​(λ)‖2).≔superscript𝜎21superscript𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛11𝑝superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆2superscript𝜆2𝑝superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑖𝜆¯𝑥𝜆2\sigma^{2}\coloneqq\tfrac{1}{n^{2}}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\left(\tfrac{1}{1-p}\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda))\|^{2}+\tfrac{\lambda^{2}}{p}\|x_{i}(\lambda)-\overline{x}(\lambda)\|^{2}\right).

Let us find the parameters p𝑝p, α𝛼\alpha which lead to the fastest rate, to push the error within (𝒪​(ε)+2​n​α​σ2μ)𝒪𝜀2𝑛𝛼superscript𝜎2𝜇\left({\cal O}(\varepsilon)+\tfrac{2n\alpha\sigma^{2}}{\mu}\right)-neighborhood of the optimum777In Sec. 5 we propose a variance reduced algorithm which removes the (2​n​α​σ2μ)2𝑛𝛼superscript𝜎2𝜇(\tfrac{2n\alpha\sigma^{2}}{\mu})-neighborhood from Thm. 4.5. In that setting, our goal will be to achieve 𝔼​[‖xk−x​(λ)‖2]≤ε​‖x0−x​(λ)‖2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑘𝑥𝜆2𝜀superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥0𝑥𝜆2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|x^{k}-x(\lambda)\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\varepsilon\left\|x^{0}-x(\lambda)\right\|^{2}. , i.e., to achieve

𝔼​[‖xk−x​(λ)‖2]≤ε​‖x0−x​(λ)‖2+2​n​α​σ2μ.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑘𝑥𝜆2𝜀superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥0𝑥𝜆22𝑛𝛼superscript𝜎2𝜇\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|x^{k}-x(\lambda)\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\varepsilon\left\|x^{0}-x(\lambda)\right\|^{2}+\tfrac{2n\alpha\sigma^{2}}{\mu}. (10)
Corollary 4.6

The value p⋆=λL+λsuperscript𝑝⋆𝜆𝐿𝜆p^{\star}=\tfrac{\lambda}{L+\lambda} minimizes both the number of iterations and the expected number of communications for achieving (10). In particular, the optimal number of iterations is 2​L+λμ​log⁡1ε2𝐿𝜆𝜇1𝜀2\tfrac{L+\lambda}{\mu}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}, and the optimal expected number of communications is 2​λλ+L​Lμ​log⁡1ε.2𝜆𝜆𝐿𝐿𝜇1𝜀\tfrac{2\lambda}{\lambda+L}\tfrac{L}{\mu}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}.

If we choose p=p⋆𝑝superscript𝑝⋆p=p^{\star}, then α​λn​p=12𝛼𝜆𝑛𝑝12\tfrac{\alpha\lambda}{np}=\tfrac{1}{2}, and the aggregation rule (9) in Algorithm 1 becomes

xik+1=12​(xik+x¯k)subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘1𝑖12subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscript¯𝑥𝑘x^{k+1}_{i}=\tfrac{1}{2}\left(x^{k}_{i}+\bar{x}^{k}\right) (11)

while the local GD step (8) becomes xik+1=xik−12​L​∇fi​(xik).subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘𝑖12𝐿∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑘x^{k+1}_{i}=x^{k}_{i}-\tfrac{1}{2L}\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}^{k}).

Notice that while our method does not support full averaging as that is too unstable, (11) suggests that one should take a large step towards averaging. As λ𝜆\lambda get smaller, the solution to the optimization problem (2) will increasingly favour pure local models, i.e., xi​(λ)→xi​(0)≔arg⁡min⁡fi→subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖0≔subscript𝑓𝑖x_{i}(\lambda)\to x_{i}(0)\coloneqq\arg\min f_{i} for all i𝑖i as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0. Pure local models can be computed without any communication whatsoever and Cor. 4.6 confirms this intuition: the optimal number of communication round decreases to zero as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0. On the other hand, as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, the optimal number of communication rounds converges to 2​Lμ​log⁡1ε2𝐿𝜇1𝜀2\tfrac{L}{\mu}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}, which recovers the performance of GD for finding the globally optimal model (see Fig. 1).

In summary, we recover the communication efficiency of GD for finding the globally optimal model as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty (ignoring the (2​n​α​σ2μ)2𝑛𝛼superscript𝜎2𝜇(\tfrac{2n\alpha\sigma^{2}}{\mu})-neighborhood). However, for other values of λ𝜆\lambda, the communication complexity of L2GD is better and decreases to 00 as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0. Hence, our communication complexity result interpolates between the communication complexity of GD for finding the global model and the zero communication complexity for finding the pure local models.

L2GD and full averaging.

Is there a setup such that conditions of Thm. 4.5 are satisfied and the aggregation update (9) is identical to full averaging? This is equivalent requiring 0<p<10𝑝10<p<1 such that α​λ=n​p𝛼𝜆𝑛𝑝\alpha\lambda=np. However, we have α​λ≤λ2​ℒ≤n​p𝛼𝜆𝜆2ℒ𝑛𝑝\alpha\lambda\leq\tfrac{\lambda}{2{\cal L}}\leq np, which means that full averaging is not supported by our theory.

5 Loopless Local SGD with Variance Reduction

As we have seen in Sec. 4.3, L2GD is a specific instance of SGD, thus only converges linearly to a neighborhood of the optimum. In this section, we resolve the mentioned issue by incorporating control variates to the stochastic gradient (Johnson & Zhang, 2013; Defazio et al., 2014). We go further: we assume that each local objective has a finite-sum structure and propose an algorithm, L2SGD+, which takes local stochastic gradient steps, while maintaining (global) linear convergence rate. As a consequence, L2SGD+ is the first local SGD with linear convergence.888We are aware that a linearly converging local SGD (with λ=∞𝜆\lambda=\infty) can be obtained as a particular instance of the decoupling method (Mishchenko & Richtárik, 2019). Other variance reduced local SGD algorithms (Liang et al., 2019; Karimireddy et al., 2019; Wu et al., 2019) do not achieve linear convergence. For convenience, we present variance reduced local GD (i.e., no local subsampling) in the Appendix.

Assumption 5.1

Assume that fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} has a finite-sum structure:

fi​(xi)=1m​∑j=1mfi,j′​(xi).subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖f_{i}(x_{{i}})=\tfrac{1}{m}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{m}f^{\prime}_{i,j}(x_{{i}}).

Let fi,j′subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖𝑗f^{\prime}_{i,j} be convex, L′superscript𝐿′{L^{\prime}}-smooth while fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex (for each 1≤j≤m,1≤i≤nformulae-sequence1𝑗𝑚1𝑖𝑛1\leq j\leq m,1\leq{i}\leq{n}).

5.1 Algorithm

Denote 𝟏∈ℝm1superscriptℝ𝑚{\bf 1}\in\mathbb{R}^{m} to be vector of ones. We are now ready to state L2SGD+ as Algorithm 2.

L2SGD+ only communicates when a two consecutive coin tosses land a different value, thus, on average p​(1−p)​k𝑝1𝑝𝑘p(1-p)k times per k𝑘k iterations. However, L2SGD+ requires communication of control variates 𝐉i​𝟏,𝚿isubscript𝐉𝑖1subscript𝚿𝑖{\bf J}_{i}{\bf 1},{\bf\Psi}_{i} as well – each communication round is thus three times more expensive. In the Appendix, we provide an implementation of L2SGD+ that does not require the communication of 𝐉i​𝟏,𝚿isubscript𝐉𝑖1subscript𝚿𝑖{\bf J}_{i}{\bf 1},{\bf\Psi}_{i}.

5.2 Convergence theory

We are now ready to present a convergence rate of L2SGD+ (the algorithm, along with the efficient implementation is presented in Appendix B.2).

Theorem 5.1

Let Assumption 5.1 hold and choose α=n​min⁡{(1−p)4​L′+μ​m,p4​λ+μ}.𝛼𝑛1𝑝4superscript𝐿′𝜇𝑚𝑝4𝜆𝜇\alpha={n}\min\left\{\tfrac{(1-{p})}{4{L^{\prime}}+\mu m},\tfrac{{p}}{4\lambda+\mu}\right\}. Then the iteration complexity of Algorithm 2 is

max⁡{4​L′+μ​m(1−p)​μ,4​λ+μp​μ}​log⁡1ε.4superscript𝐿′𝜇𝑚1𝑝𝜇4𝜆𝜇𝑝𝜇1𝜀\max\left\{\tfrac{4{L^{\prime}}+\mu m}{(1-{p})\mu},\tfrac{4\lambda+\mu}{{p}\mu}\right\}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}.

Next, we find the value of p𝑝p that yields both the best iteration and communication complexity.

Corollary 5.2

Both communication and iteration complexity of L2SGD+ are minimized for p=4​λ+μ4​λ+4​L′+(m+1)​μ𝑝4𝜆𝜇4𝜆4superscript𝐿′𝑚1𝜇{p}=\tfrac{4\lambda+\mu}{4\lambda+4{L^{\prime}}+(m+1)\mu}. The resulting iteration complexity is (4​λμ+4​L′μ+m+1)​log⁡1ε4𝜆𝜇4superscript𝐿′𝜇𝑚11𝜀\left(4\tfrac{\lambda}{\mu}+4\tfrac{{L^{\prime}}}{\mu}+m+1\right)\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}, while the communication complexity is

4​λ+μ4​L′+4​λ+(m+1)​μ​(4​L′μ+m)​log⁡1ε.4𝜆𝜇4superscript𝐿′4𝜆𝑚1𝜇4superscript𝐿′𝜇𝑚1𝜀\tfrac{4\lambda+\mu}{4{L^{\prime}}+4\lambda+(m+1)\mu}\left(4\tfrac{{L^{\prime}}}{\mu}+m\right)\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}.

Note that with λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\rightarrow\infty, the communication complexity of L2SGD+ tends to (4​L′μ+m)​log⁡1ε4superscript𝐿′𝜇𝑚1𝜀\left(4\tfrac{{L^{\prime}}}{\mu}+m\right)\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}, which is communication complexity of minibatch SAGA to find the globally optimal model (Hanzely & Richtárik, 2019). On the other hand, in the pure local setting (λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0), the communication complexity becomes log⁡1ϵ1italic-ϵ\log\tfrac{1}{\epsilon} – this is because the Lyapunov function involves a term that measures the distance of local models, which requires communication to be estimated.

Remark 5.3

L2SGD+ is the simplest local SGD method with variance reduction. In the Appendix, we present L2SGD++ which allows for 1) an arbitrary number of data points per client and arbitrary local subsampling, 2) partial participation of clients, and 3) local SVRG-like updates of control variates (thus better memory). Lastly, L2SGD++ exploits the complex smoothness structure of the local objectives, resulting in tighter rates.

6 Experiments

In this section, we numerically verify the theoretical claims from this paper. We only present a single experiment here, all remaining ones along with the missing details about the setup are in the Appendix. In particular, the Appendix includes two more experiments. The first one studies how p𝑝{p} (parameter determining the communication frequency) influences the convergence of L2SGD+. The second experiment aims to examine the effect of parameter λ𝜆\lambda on the convergence rate of L2SGD+. Both of these experiments confirm our theoretical findings

We consider logistic regression problem with LibSVM data (Chang & Lin, 2011). The data were normalized so that fi,j′subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖𝑗f^{\prime}_{i,j} is 1-smooth for each j𝑗j, while the local objectives are 10−4superscript10410^{-4}-strongly convex. In order to cover a range of possible scenarios, we have chosen a different number of clients for each dataset (see the Appendix). Lastly, the stepsize was always chosen according to Thm. 5.1.

We compare three different methods: L2SGD+, L2GD with local subsampling (L2SGD in the Appendix), and L2GD with local subsampling and control variates constructed for ψ𝜓\psi only (L2SGD2 in the Appendix; similar to (Liang et al., 2019)). We expect L2SGD+ to converge to the global optimum linearly, while both L2SGD and L2SGD2 to converge to certain neighborhood. Each method is applied to two objectives constructed by a different split of the data among the devices. For the homogeneous split, we randomly reshuffle the data. For heterogeneous split, we first sort the data based on the labels and then construct the local objectives according to the current order.

Fig. 3 demonstrates the importance of variance reduction – it ensures a fast global convergence of L2SGD+, while the neighborhood is slightly smaller for L2SGD2 compared to L2SGD. As predicted, data heterogeneity does not affect the convergence speed of the proposed methods.

7 Possible Extensions

Our analysis of L2GD can be extended to cover smooth convex and non-convex loss functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} (we do not explore these directions). Further, our methods can be extended to a decentralized regime where the devices correspond to devices of a connected network, and communication is allowed along the edges of the graph only. This can be achieved by introducing an additional randomization over the penalty ψ𝜓\psi. Further, our approach can be accelerated in the sense of Nesterov (Nesterov, 2004) by adapting the a variant of Katyusha (Allen-Zhu, 2017; Qian et al., 2019a) to our setting, thus further reducing the number of communication rounds.

Appendix A Experimental Setup and Further Experiments 

In all experiments in this paper, we consider a simple binary classification model – logistic regression. In particular, suppose that device i𝑖{i} owns data matrix 𝐀i∈ℝm×dsubscript𝐀𝑖superscriptℝ𝑚𝑑{\bf A}_{{i}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times d} along with corresponding labels bi∈{−1,1}msubscript𝑏𝑖superscript11𝑚b_{{i}}\in\{-1,1\}^{m}. The local objective for client i𝑖{i} is then given as follows

fi​(x)≔1m​∑j=1mfi,j′​(x)+μ2​‖x‖2,wherefi​m+j′​(x)=log⁡(1+exp⁡((𝐀i)j,:​x⋅bi)).formulae-sequence≔subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖𝑗𝑥𝜇2superscriptnorm𝑥2wheresubscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖𝑚𝑗𝑥1⋅subscriptsubscript𝐀𝑖𝑗:𝑥subscript𝑏𝑖f_{{i}}(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}f^{\prime}_{{i},j}(x)+\frac{\mu}{2}\|x\|^{2},\quad\text{where}\quad f^{\prime}_{{i}m+j}(x)=\log\left(1+\exp\left(({\bf A}_{{i}})_{j,:}x\cdot b_{{i}}\right)\right).

The rows of data matrix 𝐀𝐀{\bf A} were normalized to have length 4 so that each fi,j′subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖𝑗f^{\prime}_{i,j} is 111-smooth for each j𝑗j. At the same time, the local objective on each device is 10−4superscript10410^{-4} strongly convex. Next, datasets are from LibSVM (Chang & Lin, 2011).

In each case, we consider the simplest locally stochastic algorithm. In particular, each dataset is evenly split among the clients, while the local stochastic method samples a single data point each iteration.

We have chosen a different number of clients for each dataset – so that we cover different possible scenarios. See Table 1 for details (it also includes sizes of the datasets). Lastly, the stepsize was always chosen according to Thm. 5.1.

A.1 Comparison of the methods

In our first experiment, we verify two phenomena:

  • •

    The effect of variance reduction on the convergence speed of local methods. We compare 3 different methods: local SGD with full variance reduction (Algorithm 2), shifted local SGD (Algorithm 7) and local SGD (Algorithm 6). Our theory predicts that a fully variance reduced algorithm converges to the global optimum linearly, while both shifted local SGD and local SGD converge to a neighborhood of the optimum. At the same time, the neighborhood should be smaller for shifted local SGD.

  • •

    The claim that heterogeneity of the data does not influence the convergence rate. We consider two splits of the data heterogeneous and homogeneous. For the homogeneous split, we first randomly reshuffle the data and then construct the local objectives according to the current order (i.e., the first client owns the first m𝑚m indices, etc.). For heterogeneous split, we first sort the data based on the labels and then construct the local objectives accordingly (thus achieving the worst-case heterogeneity). Note that the overall objective to solve is different in homogeneous and heterogeneous case – we thus plot relative suboptimality of the objective (i.e., F​(xk)−F​(x⋆)F​(x0)−F​(x⋆)𝐹superscript𝑥𝑘𝐹superscript𝑥⋆𝐹superscript𝑥0𝐹superscript𝑥⋆\tfrac{F(x^{k})-F(x^{\star})}{F(x^{0})-F(x^{\star})}) to directly compare the convergence speed.

In each experiment, we choose p=0.1𝑝0.1{p}=0.1 and λ=19𝜆19\lambda=\tfrac{1}{9} – such choice mean that p𝑝{p} is very close to optimal. The other parameters (i.e., number of clients) are provided in Table 1. Fig. 4 presents the result.

As expected, Figure 4 clearly demonstrates the following:

  • •

    Full variance reduction always converges to the global optima, methods with partial variance reduction only converge to a neighborhood of the optimum.

  • •

    Partial variance reduction (i.e., shifting the local SGD) is better than not using control variates at all. Although the improvement in the performance is rather negligible.

  • •

    Data heterogeneity does not affect the convergence speed of the proposed methods. Therefore, unlike standard local SGD, mixing the local and global models does not suffer the problems with heterogeneity.

A.2 Effect of p𝑝{p}

In the second experiment, we study the effect of p𝑝{p} on the convergence rate of variance reduced local SGD. Note that p𝑝{p} immediately influences the number of communication rounds – on average, the clients take (p−1−1)superscript𝑝11({p}^{-1}-1) local steps in between two consecutive rounds of communication (aggregation).

In Section 5, we argue that, it is optimal (in terms of the convergence rate) to choose p𝑝{p} of order p⋆≔λL′+λ≔superscript𝑝⋆𝜆superscript𝐿′𝜆{p}^{\star}\coloneqq\tfrac{\lambda}{{L^{\prime}}+\lambda}. Figure 5 compares p=p⋆𝑝superscript𝑝⋆{p}={p}^{\star} against other values of p𝑝{p} and confirms its optimality (in terms of optimizing the convergence rate).

While the slower convergence of Algorithm 2 with p<p⋆𝑝superscript𝑝⋆{p}<{p}^{\star} is expected (i.e., communicating more frequently yields a faster convergence), slower convergence for p>p⋆𝑝superscript𝑝⋆{p}>{p}^{\star} is rather surprising; in fact, it means that communicating less frequently yields faster convergence. This effect takes place due to the specific structure of problem (12); it would be lost when enforcing x1=⋯=xnsubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1}=\dots=x_{{n}} (corresponding to λ=∞𝜆\lambda=\infty).

A.3 Effect of λ𝜆\lambda

In this experiment we study how different values of λ𝜆\lambda influence the convergence rate of Algorithm 2, given that everything else (i.e., p𝑝{p}) is fixed. Note that for each value of λ𝜆\lambda we get a different instance of problem (12); thus the optimal solution is different as well. Therefore, in order to make a fair comparison between convergence speeds, we plot the relative suboptimality (i.e., F​(xk)−F​(x⋆)F​(x0)−F​(x⋆)𝐹superscript𝑥𝑘𝐹superscript𝑥⋆𝐹superscript𝑥0𝐹superscript𝑥⋆\tfrac{F(x^{k})-F(x^{\star})}{F(x^{0})-F(x^{\star})}) against the data passes. Figure 6 presents the results.

The complexity of Algorithm 2 is999Given that μ𝜇\mu is small. 𝒪​(L′(1−p)​μ)​log⁡1ε𝒪superscript𝐿′1𝑝𝜇1𝜀{\cal O}\left(\tfrac{{L^{\prime}}}{(1-{p})\mu}\right)\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon} as soon as λ<λ⋆≔L​p(1−p)𝜆superscript𝜆⋆≔𝐿𝑝1𝑝\lambda<\lambda^{\star}\coloneqq\tfrac{L{p}}{(1-{p})}; otherwise the complexity is 𝒪​(λp​μ)​log⁡1ε𝒪𝜆𝑝𝜇1𝜀{\cal O}\left(\tfrac{\lambda}{{p}\mu}\right)\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}. This perfectly consistent with what Figure 6 shows – the choice λ<λ⋆𝜆superscript𝜆⋆\lambda<\lambda^{\star} resulted in comparable convergence speed than λ=λ⋆𝜆superscript𝜆⋆\lambda=\lambda^{\star}; while the choice λ>λ⋆𝜆superscript𝜆⋆\lambda>\lambda^{\star} yields noticeably worse rate than λ=λ⋆𝜆superscript𝜆⋆\lambda=\lambda^{\star}.

Appendix B Remaining Algorithms

B.1 Local GD with variance reduction

In this section, we present variance reduced local gradient descent with partial aggregation. In particular, the proposed algorithm (Algorithm 3) incorporates control variates to Algorithm 1. Therefore, the proposed method can be seen as a special case of Algorithm 2 with m=1𝑚1m=1. We thus only present it for pedagogical purposes, as it might shed additional insights into our approach.

In particular, the update rule of proposed method will be xk+1=xk−α​gksuperscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘𝛼superscript𝑔𝑘x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\alpha g^{k} where

gk={p−1​(λ​∇ψ​(xk)−n−1​𝚿k)+n−1​𝐉k+n−1​𝚿kwith probabilityp(1−p)−1​(∇f​(xk)−n−1​𝐉k)+n−1​𝐉k+n−1​𝚿kwith probability1−p.superscript𝑔𝑘casessuperscript𝑝1𝜆∇𝜓superscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑛1superscript𝚿𝑘superscript𝑛1superscript𝐉𝑘superscript𝑛1superscript𝚿𝑘with probability𝑝superscript1𝑝1∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑛1superscript𝐉𝑘superscript𝑛1superscript𝐉𝑘superscript𝑛1superscript𝚿𝑘with probability1𝑝g^{k}=\begin{cases}{p}^{-1}(\lambda\nabla\psi(x^{k})-{n}^{-1}{\bf\Psi}^{k})+{n}^{-1}{\bf J}^{k}+{n}^{-1}{\bf\Psi}^{k}&\text{with probability}\quad{p}\\ (1-{p})^{-1}(\nabla f(x^{k})-{n}^{-1}{\bf J}^{k})+{n}^{-1}{\bf J}^{k}+{n}^{-1}{\bf\Psi}^{k}&\text{with probability}\quad 1-{p}\end{cases}.

for some control variates vectors 𝐉k,𝚿k∈ℝn​dsuperscript𝐉𝑘superscript𝚿𝑘superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑{\bf J}^{k},{\bf\Psi}^{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{nd}. A quick check gives

𝔼​[gk|xk]=∇f​(xk)+λ​∇ψ​(xk)=∇F​(xk),𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscript𝑔𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘𝜆∇𝜓superscript𝑥𝑘∇𝐹superscript𝑥𝑘\mathbb{E}\left[g^{k}\,|\,x^{k}\right]=\nabla f(x^{k})+\lambda\nabla\psi(x^{k})=\nabla F(x^{k}),

A specific, distributed implementation of the described method is presented as Algorithm 3. The only communication between the devices takes place when the average model x¯ksuperscript¯𝑥𝑘\bar{x}^{k} is being computed (with probability p𝑝{p}), which is analogous to standard local SGD. Therefore we aim to set p𝑝{p} rather small.

Note that Algorithm 3 is a particular special case of SAGA with importance sampling (Qian et al., 2019b); thus, we obtain convergence rate of the method for free. We state it as Thm. B.1.

Theorem B.1

Let Assumption 3.1 hold. Set α=n​min⁡((1−p)4​L+μ,p4​λ+μ)𝛼𝑛1𝑝4𝐿𝜇𝑝4𝜆𝜇\alpha={n}\min\left(\tfrac{(1-{p})}{4L+\mu},\tfrac{{p}}{4\lambda+\mu}\right). Then, iteration complexity of Algorithm 3 is

max⁡(4​L+μμ​(1−p),4​λ+μμ​p)​log⁡1ε.4𝐿𝜇𝜇1𝑝4𝜆𝜇𝜇𝑝1𝜀\max\left(\tfrac{4L+\mu}{\mu(1-{p})},\tfrac{4\lambda+\mu}{\mu{p}}\right)\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}.

Proof: Clearly,

Corollary B.2

Iteration complexity of Algorithm 3 is minimized for p=4​λ+μ4​λ+4​L+2​μ𝑝4𝜆𝜇4𝜆4𝐿2𝜇{p}=\tfrac{4\lambda+\mu}{4\lambda+4L+2\mu}, which yields complexity 4​(λμ+Lμ+12)​log⁡1ε4𝜆𝜇𝐿𝜇121𝜀4\left(\tfrac{\lambda}{\mu}+\tfrac{L}{\mu}+\tfrac{1}{2}\right)\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}. The communication complexity is minimized for any p≤4​λ+μ4​λ+4​L+2​μ𝑝4𝜆𝜇4𝜆4𝐿2𝜇{p}\leq\tfrac{4\lambda+\mu}{4\lambda+4L+2\mu}, in which case the total number of communication rounds to reach ε𝜀\varepsilon-solution is (4​λμ+1)​log⁡1ε4𝜆𝜇11𝜀\left(\tfrac{4\lambda}{\mu}+1\right)\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}.

As a direct consequence of Corollary B.2 we see that the optimal choice of p𝑝p that minimizes both communication and number of iterations to reach ε𝜀\varepsilon solution of problem (17) is p=4​λ+μ4​λ+4​L+2​μ𝑝4𝜆𝜇4𝜆4𝐿2𝜇{p}=\tfrac{4\lambda+\mu}{4\lambda+4L+2\mu}.

Remark B.3

While both Algorithm 3 and Algorithm 2 are a special case of SAGA, the practical version of variance reduced local SGD (presented in Section B.3) is not. In particular, we wish to run the SVRG-like method locally in order to avoid storing the full gradient table.111111SAGA does not require storing a full gradient table for problems with linear models by memorizing the residuals. However, in full generality, SVRG-like methods are preferable. Therefore, variance reduced local SGD that will be proposed in Section B.3 is neither a special case of SAGA nor a special case of SVRG (or a variant of SVRG). However, it is still a special case of a more general algorithm from (Hanzely & Richtárik, 2019).

As mentioned, Algorithm 2 is a generalization of Algorithm 3 when the local subproblem is a finite sum. Note that Algorithm 3 constructs a control variates for both local subproblem and aggregation function ψ𝜓\psi and constructs corresponding unbiased gradient estimator. In contrast, Algorithm 2 constructs extra control variates within the local subproblem in order to reduce the variance of gradient estimator coming from the local subsampling.

B.2 L2SGD+: Algorithm and the efficient implementation

Here we present an efficient implementation of L2SGD+ as Algorithm 4 so that we do not have to communicate control variates. As a consequence, Algorithm 4 needs to communicate on average p​(1−p)​k𝑝1𝑝𝑘p(1-p)k times per k𝑘k iterations, while each communication consists of sending only local models to the master and back.

B.3 Local SGD with variance reduction – general method

In this section, we present a fully general variance reduced local SGD. We consider a more general instance of (2) where each local objective includes a possibly nonsmooth regularizer, which admits a cheap evaluation of proximal operator. In particular, the objective becomes

Furthermore, assume that Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} is convex for 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq{i}\leq{n}.

Our method (Algotihm 5) allows for arbitrary aggregation probability (same as Algorithms 3, 2), arbitrary sampling of clients (to model the inactive clients) and arbitrary structure/sampling of the local objectives (i.e., arbitrary size of local datasets, arbitrary smoothness structure of each local objective and arbitrary subsampling strategy of each client). Moreover, it allows for the SVRG-like update rule of local control variates 𝐉ksuperscript𝐉𝑘{\bf J}^{k}, which requires less storage given an efficient implementation.

To be specific, each device owns a distribution 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}{\cal D}}_{i} over subsets of misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}. When the aggregation is not performed (with probability 1−p1𝑝1-{p}), a subset of active devices S𝑆{\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}S} is selected (S𝑆{\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}S} follows arbitrary fixed distribution 𝒟𝒟{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}{\cal D}}). Each of the active clients (i∈S𝑖𝑆{i}\in{\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}S}) samples a subset of local indices Si∼𝒟isimilar-tosubscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖S_{i}\sim{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}{\cal D}}_{{i}} and observe the corresponding part of local Jacobian 𝐆i​(xk)(:,Si)subscript𝐆𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘:subscript𝑆𝑖{\bf G}_{i}(x^{k})_{(:,S_{i})} (where 𝐆i(xk)≔[∇fi,1′(xk),∇fi,2′(xk),…∇fi,mi′(xk){\bf G}_{{i}}(x^{k})\coloneqq[\nabla f^{\prime}_{{i},1}(x^{k}),\nabla f^{\prime}_{{i},2}(x^{k}),\dots\nabla f^{\prime}_{{i},m_{i}}(x^{k})). When the aggregation is performed (with probability p𝑝{p}) we evaluate x¯ksuperscript¯𝑥𝑘\bar{x}^{k} and distribute it to each device; using which each device computes a corresponding component of λ​∇ψ​(xk)𝜆∇𝜓superscript𝑥𝑘\lambda\nabla\psi(x^{k}). Those are the key components in constructing the unbiased gradient estimator (without control variates).

It remains to construct control variates and unbiased gradient estimator. If the aggregation is done, we just simply replace the last column of the gradient table. If the aggregation is not done, we have two options – either keep replacing the columns of the Jacobian table (in such case, we obtain a particular case of SAGA (Defazio et al., 2014)) or do LSVRG-like replacement (Hofmann et al., 2015; Kovalev et al., 2020) (in such case, the algorithm is a particular case of GJS (Hanzely & Richtárik, 2019), but is not a special case of neither SAGA nor LSVRG. Note that LSVRG-like replacement is preferrable in practice due to a better memory efficiency (one does not need to store the whole gradient table) for the models other than linear.

In order to keep the gradient estimate unbiased, it will be convenient to define vector pi∈ℝmisubscript𝑝𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑚𝑖{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}p}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}} such that for each j∈{1,…,mi}𝑗1…subscript𝑚𝑖j\in\{1,\dots,m_{i}\} we have ℙ​(j∈Si)=pi,jℙ𝑗subscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗\mathbb{P}\left(j\in S_{i}\right)={\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}p}_{i,j}.

Next, to give a tight rate for any given pair of smoothness structure and sampling strategy, we use a standard tool first proposed for the analysis of randomized coordinate descent methods (Richtárik & Takáč, 2016; Qu & Richtárik, 2016) called Expected Separable Overapproximation (ESO) assumption. ESO provides us with smoothness parameters of the objective which “account” for the given sampling strategy.

Assumption B.2

Suppose that there is vi∈ℝmisubscript𝑣𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑚𝑖v_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}} such for each client we have:

(14)

Lastly, denote pisubscript𝑝𝑖{\color[rgb]{.75,0,.25}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.75,0,.25}p}_{i} to be the probability that worker i𝑖{i} is active and 𝟏(mi)∈ℝmisuperscript1subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑚𝑖{\bf 1}^{(m_{i})}\in\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}} to be the vector of ones. The resulting algorithm is stated as Algorithm 5.

Remark B.6

Algotihm 3 is a special case of Algorithm 2 which is in turn special case of Algorithm 5. Similarly, Theorem 3 is a special case of Theorem 5.1 which is again special case of Theorem B.4.

B.4 Local stochastic algorithms

In this section, we present two more algorithms – Local SGD with partial variance reduction (Algorithm 7) and Local SGD without variance reduction (Algorithm 6). While Algorithm 6 uses no control variates at all (thus is essentially Algorithm 1 where local gradient descent steps are replaced with local SGD steps), Algorithm 7 constructs control variates for ψ𝜓\psi only, resulting in locally drifted SGD algorithm (with the constant drift between each consecutive rounds of communication). While we do not present the convergence rates of the methods here, we shall notice they can be easily obtained using the framework from (Gorbunov et al., 2020).

Appendix C Missing Lemmas and Proofs

C.1 Gradient and Hessian of ψ𝜓\psi

Let 𝐈𝐈{\bf I} be the d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d identity matrix and 𝐈nsubscript𝐈𝑛{\bf I}_{n} be n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n identity matrix. Then, we have

Proof:

C.2 Proof of Theorem 3.1

For any λ,θ≥0𝜆𝜃0\lambda,\theta\geq 0 we have

f​(x​(λ))+λ​ψ​(x​(λ))𝑓𝑥𝜆𝜆𝜓𝑥𝜆\displaystyle f(x(\lambda))+\lambda\psi(x(\lambda)) ≤\displaystyle\leq f​(x​(θ))+λ​ψ​(x​(θ))𝑓𝑥𝜃𝜆𝜓𝑥𝜃\displaystyle f(x(\theta))+\lambda\psi(x(\theta)) (15)
f​(x​(θ))+θ​ψ​(x​(θ))𝑓𝑥𝜃𝜃𝜓𝑥𝜃\displaystyle f(x(\theta))+\theta\psi(x(\theta)) ≤\displaystyle\leq f​(x​(λ))+θ​ψ​(x​(λ)).𝑓𝑥𝜆𝜃𝜓𝑥𝜆\displaystyle f(x(\lambda))+\theta\psi(x(\lambda)). (16)

By adding inequalities (15) and (16), we get

(θ−λ)​(ψ​(x​(λ))−ψ​(x​(θ)))≥0,𝜃𝜆𝜓𝑥𝜆𝜓𝑥𝜃0(\theta-\lambda)(\psi(x(\lambda))-\psi(x(\theta)))\geq 0,

which means that ψ​(x​(λ))𝜓𝑥𝜆\psi(x(\lambda)) is decreasing in λ𝜆\lambda. Assume λ≥θ𝜆𝜃\lambda\geq\theta. From the (16) we get

f​(x​(λ))≥f​(x​(θ))+θ​(ψ​(x​(θ))−ψ​(x​(λ)))≥f​(x​(θ)),𝑓𝑥𝜆𝑓𝑥𝜃𝜃𝜓𝑥𝜃𝜓𝑥𝜆𝑓𝑥𝜃f(x(\lambda))\geq f(x(\theta))+\theta(\psi(x(\theta))-\psi(x(\lambda)))\geq f(x(\theta)),

where the last inequality follows since θ≥0𝜃0\theta\geq 0 and since ψ​(x​(θ))≥ψ​(x​(λ))𝜓𝑥𝜃𝜓𝑥𝜆\psi(x(\theta))\geq\psi(x(\lambda)). So, f​(x​(λ))𝑓𝑥𝜆f(x(\lambda)) is increasing.

Notice that since ψ𝜓\psi is a non-negative function and since x​(λ)𝑥𝜆x(\lambda) minimizes F𝐹F and ψ​(x​(∞))=0𝜓𝑥0\psi(x(\infty))=0, we have

f​(x​(0))≤f​(x​(λ))≤f​(x​(λ))+λ​ψ​(x​(λ))≤f​(x​(∞)),𝑓𝑥0𝑓𝑥𝜆𝑓𝑥𝜆𝜆𝜓𝑥𝜆𝑓𝑥f(x(0))\leq f(x(\lambda))\leq f(x(\lambda))+\lambda\psi(x(\lambda))\leq f(x(\infty)),

which implies (3) and (4).

C.3 Proof of Theorem 3.2

The equation ∇F​(x​(λ))=0∇𝐹𝑥𝜆0\nabla F(x(\lambda))=0 can be equivalently written as

∇fi​(xi​(λ))+λ​(xi​(λ)−x¯​(λ))=0,i=1,2,…,n,formulae-sequence∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆¯𝑥𝜆0𝑖12…𝑛\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda))+\lambda(x_{i}(\lambda)-\overline{x}(\lambda))=0,\qquad i=1,2,\dots,n,

which is identical to (5). Averaging these identities over i𝑖i, we get

x¯​(λ)=x¯​(λ)−1λ​1n​∑i=1n∇fi​(xi​(λ)),¯𝑥𝜆¯𝑥𝜆1𝜆1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆\overline{x}(\lambda)=\overline{x}(\lambda)-\tfrac{1}{\lambda}\tfrac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda)),

which implies

∑i=1n∇fi​(xi​(λ))=0.superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆0\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda))=0.

ψ​(x​(λ))=12​n​∑i=1n‖xi​(λ)−x¯​(λ)‖2=12​n​λ2​∑i=1n‖∇fi​(xi​(λ))‖2=12​λ2​‖∇f​(x​(λ))‖2,𝜓𝑥𝜆12𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑖𝜆¯𝑥𝜆212𝑛superscript𝜆2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆212superscript𝜆2superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝑥𝜆2\psi(x(\lambda))=\tfrac{1}{2n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|x_{i}(\lambda)-\overline{x}(\lambda)\right\|^{2}=\tfrac{1}{2n\lambda^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda))\right\|^{2}=\tfrac{1}{2\lambda^{2}}\left\|\nabla f(x(\lambda))\right\|^{2},

as desired.

C.4 Proof of Theorem 3.3

First, observe that

‖∇P​(x¯​(λ))‖2=‖1n​∑i∇fi​(x¯​(λ))‖2=‖1n​∑i∇fi​(x¯​(λ))−1n​∑i∇fi​(xi​(λ))‖2,superscriptnorm∇𝑃¯𝑥𝜆2superscriptnorm1𝑛subscript𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖¯𝑥𝜆2superscriptnorm1𝑛subscript𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖¯𝑥𝜆1𝑛subscript𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆2||\nabla P(\bar{x}(\lambda))||^{2}=\left\|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}\nabla f_{i}(\bar{x}(\lambda))\right\|^{2}=\left\|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}\nabla f_{i}(\bar{x}(\lambda))-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda))\right\|^{2},

where the second identity is due to Theorem 3.2 which says that 1n​∑i∇fi​(xi​(λ))=01𝑛subscript𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆0\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda))=0. By applying Jensen’s inequality and Lipschitz continuity of functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, we get

‖∇P​(x¯​(λ))‖2≤1n​∑i‖∇fi​(x¯​(λ))−∇fi​(xi​(λ))‖2≤L2n​∑i‖x¯​(λ)−xi​(λ)‖2=2​L2​ψ​(x​(λ)).superscriptnorm∇𝑃¯𝑥𝜆21𝑛subscript𝑖superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖¯𝑥𝜆∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆2superscript𝐿2𝑛subscript𝑖superscriptnorm¯𝑥𝜆subscript𝑥𝑖𝜆22superscript𝐿2𝜓𝑥𝜆||\nabla P(\bar{x}(\lambda))||^{2}\leq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}||\nabla f_{i}(\bar{x}(\lambda))-\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}(\lambda))||^{2}\leq\frac{L^{2}}{n}\sum_{i}||\bar{x}(\lambda)-x_{i}(\lambda)||^{2}=2L^{2}\psi(x(\lambda)).

It remains to apply (3) and notice that P𝑃P is strongly convex and thus x​(∞)𝑥x(\infty) is indeed the unique minimizer.

C.5 Proof of Theorem 4.5

We first show that our gradient estimator G​(x)𝐺𝑥G(x) satisfies the expected smoothness property (Gower et al., 2018, 2019).

Lemma C.2

C.7 Proof of Corollary 4.6

Firstly, to minimize the total number of iterations, it suffices to minimize ℒℒ{\cal L} which is achieved with p⋆=λL+λsuperscript𝑝⋆𝜆𝐿𝜆p^{\star}=\tfrac{\lambda}{L+\lambda}. (1−μ2​n​ℒ)k≤ε.superscript1𝜇2𝑛ℒ𝑘𝜀\left(1-\tfrac{\mu}{2n{\cal L}}\right)^{k}\leq\varepsilon.

The expected number of communications to achieve this goal is equal to

=\displaystyle= p​(1−p)​2​max⁡{L1−p,λp}μ​log⁡1ε𝑝1𝑝2𝐿1𝑝𝜆𝑝𝜇1𝜀\displaystyle p(1-p)\tfrac{2\max\left\{\tfrac{L}{1-p},\tfrac{\lambda}{p}\right\}}{\mu}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}
=\displaystyle= 2​max⁡{p​L,(1−p)​λ}μ​log⁡1ε.2𝑝𝐿1𝑝𝜆𝜇1𝜀\displaystyle\tfrac{2\max\left\{pL,(1-p)\lambda\right\}}{\mu}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}.

C.8 Proof of Corollary 5.2

Firstly, to minimize the total number of iterations, it suffices to solve

C.9 Proof of Theorems 5.1, B.4, and B.5

Note first that Algorithm 2 is a special case of Algorithm 5, and Theorem 5.1 immediately follows from Theorem B.4. Therefore it suffices to show Theorems B.4, and B.5. In order to do so, we will cast Algorithm 5 as a special case of GJS from (Hanzely & Richtárik, 2019). As a consequence, Theorem B.4 will be a special cases of Theorem 5.2 from (Hanzely & Richtárik, 2019).

C.9.1 GJS

In this section, we quickly summarize results from (Hanzely & Richtárik, 2019), which we cast to sho convergence rate of Algorithm 2. GJS (Hanzely & Richtárik, 2019) is a method to solve regularized empirical risk minimization objective, i.e.,

minx∈ℝd⁡1n​∑j=1nfj​(x)+R​(x).subscript𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥𝑅𝑥\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\tfrac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{n}f_{j}(x)+R(x). (17)

Defining 𝐆​(x)≔[∇f1​(x),…,∇fn​(x)]≔𝐆𝑥∇subscript𝑓1𝑥…∇subscript𝑓𝑛𝑥{\bf G}(x)\coloneqq[\nabla f_{1}(x),\dots,\nabla f_{n}(x)], we observe 𝒮​𝐆​(x),𝒰​𝐆​(x)𝒮𝐆𝑥𝒰𝐆𝑥{\cal S}{\bf G}(x),{\cal U}{\bf G}(x) every iteration where 𝒮𝒮{\cal S} is random linear projection operator and 𝒰𝒰{\cal U} is random linear operator which is identity on expectation. Based on this random gradient information, GJS (Algorithm 8) constructs variance reduced gradient estimator g𝑔g and takes a proximal step in that direction.

Next we quickly summarize theory of GJS.

Assumption C.1

Problem (17) has a unique minimizer x⋆superscript𝑥⋆x^{\star}, and f𝑓f is μ𝜇\mu-quasi strongly convex, i.e.,

f​(x⋆)≥f​(y)+⟨∇f​(y),x⋆−y⟩+μ2​‖y−x⋆‖2,∀y∈ℝd,formulae-sequence𝑓superscript𝑥⋆𝑓𝑦∇𝑓𝑦superscript𝑥⋆𝑦𝜇2superscriptnorm𝑦superscript𝑥⋆2for-all𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑f(x^{\star})\geq f(y)+\left\langle\nabla f(y),x^{\star}-y\right\rangle+\tfrac{\mu}{2}\left\|y-x^{\star}\right\|^{2},\quad\forall y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, (18)

C.9.4 Proof of Theorem 5.1
